item.title: Automate Image Resize with Padding using ImageMagick
item.description: #!/bin/sh # This script requires the download imagemagick. image_dir=$1 # First argument target_ratio="1280x960" if [ -z $image_dir ]; then echo "Please provide image directory as first argument." exit 1 fi if [ ! -d $image_dir ]; then echo "Not a valid directory" exit 1 fi output_dir="$image_dir-output" echo "Located $image_dir" echo "Creating output $output_dir" mkdir $output_dir for image in $image_dir/*; do echo "Processing $image" file_name=$(basename $image) # convert -bordercolor white -border 100 -gravity center -resize 1200x1200 -extent 1200x1200 $image $output_dir/$file_name convert -background black -gravity center -resize $target_ratio -extent $target_ratio $image $output_dir/$file_name done Resize Images Link to heading Basic usage (will overwrite the original file):

item.title: FFMPEG cheatsheet
item.description: Changing Aspect Ratio Link to heading Resizing a video from 4:3 to 16:9 (HD, 1280 x 720) for max screen size, with no cropping and addition of black padding ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -vf "scale=(iw*sar)*min(1280/(iw*sar)\,720/ih):ih*min(1280/(iw*sar)\,720/ih),pad=1280:720:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2:black" output.mp4 Explanation: *scale = FFMPEG video filter to resize a video (iw*sar)min(1280/(iwsar),720/ih) = output width of the resized video = Resize width of video to AT MOST 1280 (keeping original aspect ratio) ihmin(1280/(iwsar),720/ih) = output height of the resized video = Resize width of video to AT MOST 720 (keeping original aspect ratio) The scale transformation is then followed (chained) by a pad video filter:

item.title: Installing Blender manually in Linux
item.description: Sometimes the package manager does not give you the lastest version of the software. This guide shows you how to install Blender manually without the use of package manager in order to get the lastest version. I am using Ubuntu in this example. Download the zip file from Blender website. Unzip the file. Copy the extracted folder to somewhere else if you want to. For me I placed them in /opt folder.

item.title: Setup latest NeoVim on ubuntu with AppImage
item.description: Download NeoVim AppImage from GitHub release page. Rename nvim.appimage to nvim mv nvim.appimage nvim Set the permission: chmod +x nvim Install fuse2 library if it is required to run the appimage sudo apt install libfuse2 Copy from download folder to /usr/local/bin path /usr/bin is used for apps managed by the distribution’s package manager, so it’s not recommended to copy there. sudo mv nvim /usr/local/bin Optional Link to heading Install AstroVim

item.title: I3 configuration
item.description: My attempt on switching to a window manager (I3). I was on a pretty old laptop (GL752V), probably why I faced a handful of issues. Distro used: EndeavourOS. config file path: ~/.config/i3/config Changes made: Change open file explorer from ctrl+n to ctrl+e Make brightness key work. (See fix i3wm brightness) Resize feature with mod + ctrl + arrow keys. Ensure power button work. Make alt+F4 work as well, other than $mod + q.

item.title: Google search highlighted text
item.description: #!/bin/bash # Google search the highlighted text (requires: xdg-utils, xsel) xdg-open "[https://google.com/search?q=$(xsel)](https://google.com/search?q=$(xsel))" Bind it to a shortcut key, mine is super + s. /home/user/Desktop/scripts/google-search.sh

item.title: Change Timezone in Linux
item.description: View current timezone: timedatectl List timezones: timedatectl list-timezones Change timezone example: sudo timedatectl set-timezone Europe/Dublin

item.title: Automount Windows drive in Linux
item.description: Find out where the windows drive is located: lsblk Edit fstab file: sudo nvim /etc/fstab For example, sdb2: # <file system> <mount point> <type> <options> <dump> <pass>``` /dev/sdb2 /media/data ntfs defaults 0 0 Reboot the system: reboot Create a launcher.
